item.title: Best Credit Cards for Pet Travelers (2025)
item.description:
If you travel with your dog and aren’t using hotel credit cards, you’re leaving money on the table. Pet fees, room rates, and all those extras add up fast ‚Äî but the right cards can offset most of it with points, free nights, and elite status perks.

Here’s what I use and recommend for pet travelers.

Disclosure: This post contains affiliate links. If you apply for a card through my links, I may earn a commission at no extra cost to you. See my full disclosure for details.

Why Hotel Cards Make Sense for Pet Owners

Most pet-friendly hotels charge $50‚Äì$150 per stay in pet fees. You can’t avoid those (yet), but you can make the room itself free by booking with points. And with elite status, you get perks like room upgrades, late checkout, and free breakfast ‚Äî all of which make traveling with a dog way easier.

I haven’t paid for a hotel room in years. I use Hilton points from my credit cards, and the free night certificates cover the rest.

My Setup: The Hilton Combo

I’m loyal to Hilton because their pet policies are solid (most properties allow dogs up to 75 lbs with no breed restrictions), and their credit cards are some of the best in the game.

üíé Hilton Honors American Express Aspire

The premium option for serious travelers.
Annual Fee $550
Status Diamond (top tier)
Sign-Up Bonus 175,000 points after $6,000 spend in 6 months
Free Nights 1/year, plus more at $30k and $60k spend

This is the card if you’re serious about hotel travel. Diamond status gets you room upgrades, executive lounge access, and late checkout ‚Äî all super helpful when traveling with a dog.

That 175,000-point bonus alone is worth around 2‚Äì3 free nights at most Hilton properties. Combined with the annual free night certificate, you could have a week’s worth of hotel stays from day one.

Key perks:

  • ‚úàÔ∏è Up to $200/year in flight credits ($50/quarter)
  • üè® Up to $400/year in Hilton resort credits ($200 every 6 months)
  • üöÄ Up to $209/year CLEAR credit
  • üõéÔ∏è $100 credit at Waldorf Astoria and Conrad properties
  • üí≥ 14x points at Hilton, 7x on dining and flights, 3x everything else

üí° Pro tip: You don’t have to book flights to use the flight credit. Buy airline gift cards or add funds to your travel bank (Delta, Southwest, etc.) ‚Äî they count toward the credit and don’t expire for 5 years. Easy way to bank the $200 even if you’re not flying soon.

How the $550 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $300+
Hilton resort credits $400
Flight credits $200
CLEAR credit $209
Total $1,100+

Even if you only use half of these, you’re coming out ahead.

ü•á Hilton Honors American Express Surpass

The sweet spot for most pet travelers.
Annual Fee $150
Status Gold (Diamond at $40k/year spend)
Sign-Up Bonus 155,000 points after $3,000 spend in 6 months
Free Nights 1 after $15k spend in a calendar year

This is the sweet spot for most travelers. Gold status gets you the 5th night free on award stays, plus a daily food & beverage credit or free breakfast at most properties.

The sign-up bonus is easier to hit than the Aspire ($3k vs $6k), and 155,000 points is still enough for multiple free nights.

Key perks:

  • üè® Up to $200/year in Hilton credits ($50/quarter)
  • üí≥ 12x points at Hilton, 6x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • üåô Free night after $15k spend

üí° Pro tip: The quarterly $50 credit works on any purchase at a Hilton property ‚Äî you don’t have to be a guest. Grab dinner or drinks at a Hilton restaurant near you, and you’ve used your credit. Do that 4 times a year and you’ve made back more than the annual fee.

How the $150 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Quarterly Hilton credits $200
Total $200

Just by using the $50 quarterly credit, you’re $50 ahead before you even count the points you’re earning. If you hit the $15k spend for the free night certificate, that’s another $200+ in value.

I carry both the Aspire and Surpass. Between them, I get 2‚Äì3 free night certificates per year, plus enough points from everyday spending to cover several more nights.

üÜì Hilton Honors American Express (No Annual Fee)

The risk-free starting point.
Annual Fee $0
Status Silver
Sign-Up Bonus 100,000 points after $2,000 spend in 6 months
Free Nights None

If you’re just getting started, this is a no-risk way to begin earning Hilton points. You won’t get a free night certificate, but you still get the 5th night free benefit on award stays, which is a 20% discount on any points redemption of 5+ nights.

100,000 points for just $2,000 in spending ‚Äî with no annual fee ‚Äî is one of the best entry points into hotel rewards.

Key perks:

  • üí≥ 7x points at Hilton, 5x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • üÜì No annual fee
  • üåô 5th night free on award stays

For Kimpton Travelers: IHG & Chase Cards

Kimpton has the best pet policy in the industry ‚Äî no fees, no weight limits, no breed restrictions. If that’s your priority, you’ll need IHG points (Kimpton is part of IHG).

I don’t carry these cards yet, but they’re worth considering if Kimpton is your target.

üè® IHG One Rewards Premier Credit Card

Best if you’ll stay at IHG/Kimpton regularly.
Annual Fee $99
Sign-Up Bonus 140,000 points after $3,000 spend in 3 months
Free Night 1/year (up to 40,000 points)
Status Platinum Elite

That 140,000-point bonus is enough for 2-4 free nights at most Kimptons.

Key perks:

  • üí≥ 26x points at IHG properties
  • üåô 4th night free on award stays (book 4, pay for 3)
  • üéÅ Annual free night certificate

How the $99 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $200+
Total $200+

üÜì IHG One Rewards Traveler Credit Card

The no-risk IHG option.
Annual Fee $0
Sign-Up Bonus 80,000 points after $2,000 spend in 3 months
Free Night None

If you’re not sure how often you’ll stay at Kimpton/IHG, this gets you started with no commitment.

Key perks:

  • üí≥ 17x points at IHG properties
  • üçΩÔ∏è 3x on dining, gas, and groceries
  • üåô 4th night free on award stays (yes, even with the no-fee card)

üí≥ Chase Sapphire Preferred

Best for flexibility across multiple hotel programs.
Annual Fee $95
Sign-Up Bonus 60,000 points after $4,000 spend in 3 months

Chase Ultimate Rewards points transfer 1:1 to IHG ‚Äî and to Hyatt, Marriott, and 10+ airline partners. If you don’t want to commit to one hotel chain, this is the move.

Key perks:

  • üí≥ 3x on dining, select streaming, and online groceries
  • ‚úàÔ∏è 2x on travel
  • üîÑ Points transfer to 14+ airline and hotel partners

üí° Pro tip: If you already have Hilton cards and want to add Kimpton as an option, the Sapphire Preferred is a good complement. Transfer to IHG when you find a Kimpton you want, keep your Hilton setup for everything else.

Full breakdown: How to Book Kimpton Free with Points

The Alternative: Marriott

üè® Marriott Bonvoy Boundless

Best for Marriott loyalists.
Annual Fee $95
Status Silver Elite (Gold at $35k/year spend)
Sign-Up Bonus 3 free nights (each up to 50,000 points) after $3,000 spend in 3 months
Free Nights 1/year (up to 35,000 points, can top off with 15k more)

That sign-up bonus is huge ‚Äî 3 free nights at properties up to 50,000 points each. That could cover a long weekend at a solid Marriott property right out of the gate.

Key perks:

  • üí≥ Up to 17x points at Marriott properties
  • üçΩÔ∏è 3x on dining, groceries, and gas (first $6k/year)
  • üåô Annual free night certificate
  • ‚≠ê 15 Elite Night Credits per year

How the $95 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $200+
Total $200+

The free night certificate alone is worth at least double the annual fee at most Marriott properties. You can also top it off with up to 15,000 additional points to book nicer hotels.

Marriott’s pet policies vary more by property than Hilton’s, so always check before booking. Some Marriott brands (like Residence Inn and TownePlace Suites) tend to be more consistently pet-friendly.

Which Card Should You Get?

You… Get This Why
üÜï New to points Hilton (no fee) 100k bonus, no risk
üêï Travel 2‚Äì4x/year Hilton Surpass $200 credits > $150 fee
‚úàÔ∏è Travel frequently Hilton Aspire $1,100 in perks, Diamond upgrades
üêï‚Äçü¶∫ Have a large dog IHG Premier Kimpton has no weight limits
üîÑ Want flexibility Chase Sapphire Preferred Transfer to IHG, Hyatt, airlines
üè® Prefer Marriott Marriott Boundless 3 free nights bonus, $95 fee

How I Booked Panama City Beach for Free

For my recent 5-night trip to Panama City Beach, I used:

  • ‚úÖ Hilton points (earned from my Surpass card)
  • ‚úÖ The 5th night free benefit (book 4 nights with points, get the 5th free)

Total out of pocket for the room: $0

I still paid the $125 pet fee (5+ nights), but that’s a lot easier to stomach when the room was free.

Quick Comparison

Card Annual Fee Sign-Up Bonus Credits/Perks Free Night
üíé Hilton Aspire $550 175k points $1,100+/year Yes (annual)
ü•á Hilton Surpass $150 155k points $200/year After $15k spend
üÜì Hilton (no fee) $0 100k points ‚Äî No
üè® IHG Premier $99 140k points ‚Äî Yes (annual)
üÜì IHG Traveler $0 80k points ‚Äî No
üí≥ Chase Sapphire Preferred $95 60k points ‚Äî No
üè® Marriott Boundless $95 3 free nights ‚Äî Yes (annual)

The Bottom Line

Pet travel gets expensive fast. The right credit cards won’t eliminate pet fees, but they can make the room free ‚Äî and that’s a huge win.

The annual fees on these cards look scary at first, but once you factor in the credits and free nights, most of them pay you back more than you put in. Start with whichever card fits your budget and travel frequency, and build from there.

I’ve been running this setup for years, and it’s saved me thousands. If you’re road tripping with your dog anyway, you might as well do it for free.

Questions about which card is right for you? Reach out ‚Äî happy to help.

item.title: Best Credit Card Bonuses for Pet Travelers (December 2025)
item.description:
December is a great month to grab a new travel card. Several bonuses are at historic highs, and a few limited-time offers expire in January.

Here are the best credit card bonuses right now for pet travelers ‚Äî ranked by how useful they are for booking dog-friendly hotels.

üèÜ Top Pick: Hilton Surpass

Bonus: 155,000 Hilton Honors points after $3,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $150
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

This is the sweet spot for dog travelers. The 155,000-point bonus is enough for 3-5 free nights at most pet-friendly Hilton properties. You also get:

  • Automatic Gold status (80% bonus points on stays)
  • Up to $200/year in Hilton statement credits
  • 10 free nights toward Diamond status
  • Path to Diamond if you spend $40k/year

Why it’s great for pet travel: Every Hilton brand welcomes dogs with no breed restrictions, and most have no weight limits. Gold status gets you late checkout ‚Äî crucial when you need extra time for that morning dog walk.

My take: This is the card I recommend most. The bonus is high, the fee is reasonable, and Hilton’s footprint means you’ll always find a pet-friendly option.

üíé Premium Pick: Hilton Aspire

Bonus: 175,000 Hilton Honors points after $6,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $550
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

The Aspire is Hilton’s top-tier card, and 175,000 points is a solid bonus (though we’ve seen it higher). You get:

  • Automatic Diamond status (the top tier)
  • Free night certificate annually (worth up to $400+)
  • Up to $400/year in Hilton resort credits
  • Up to $200/year in airline fee credits
  • Priority Pass lounge access

Why it’s great for pet travel: Diamond status means complimentary breakfast at most properties and room upgrades when available. The free night certificate alone can offset the annual fee.

My take: Only worth it if you stay 10+ nights at Hilton annually. Otherwise, the Surpass is a better value.

üè® Best for Kimpton Lovers: IHG Premier

Bonus: 140,000 IHG One Rewards points after $3,000 spend in 3 months
Annual fee: $99

If you love Kimpton (and you should ‚Äî they’re the most dog-friendly chain), this is your card. The bonus gets you:

  • 3-4 free nights at most Kimpton properties
  • Automatic Platinum Elite status
  • Free night certificate annually (up to 40,000 points, can top up with more)
  • 4th night free on award stays

Why it’s great for pet travel: Kimpton has NO weight limits, NO pet fees, and NO breed restrictions. The 4th night free perk is huge ‚Äî book 4 nights and you’re essentially getting 25% off.

My take: If there’s a Kimpton where you travel, this card is a no-brainer. The $99 fee pays for itself with the annual free night.

üÜì Best No-Annual-Fee Option: Hilton Honors Card

Bonus: 100,000 Hilton Honors points after $2,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $0
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

New to points? Start here. 100,000 points with no annual fee is excellent for beginners. You get:

  • Automatic Silver status
  • 7x points at Hilton properties
  • 5th night free on award stays

Why it’s great for pet travel: Zero commitment, solid bonus. Use this to test whether Hilton works for your travel style before upgrading to the Surpass.

My take: Perfect first card. Grab it, hit the bonus, then decide if you want to upgrade later.

üè¢ Best for Business Owners: Hilton Business

Bonus: 175,000 Hilton Honors points after $8,000 spend in 6 months
Annual fee: $195
Offer expires: January 14, 2026

If you have a business (even a side hustle), this is the highest Hilton bonus available right now. You get:

  • Automatic Gold status
  • Up to $240/year in Hilton credits ($60 quarterly)
  • Path to Diamond at $40k spend
  • 12x points at Hilton, 5x on other purchases

Why it’s great for pet travel: Same Hilton benefits as the personal cards, but with a bigger bonus and better earning rates on everyday spend.

üìä Quick Comparison

Card Bonus Annual Fee Best For
Hilton Surpass 155,000 pts $150 Most pet travelers
Hilton Aspire 175,000 pts $550 Frequent Hilton guests
Hilton (No Fee) 100,000 pts $0 Beginners
Hilton Business 175,000 pts $195 Business owners
IHG Premier 140,000 pts $99 Kimpton fans

‚è∞ Offers Ending Soon

January 14, 2026:

  • All Hilton Amex card bonuses (Surpass, Aspire, No-Fee, Business)

If you’ve been thinking about a Hilton card, don’t wait until the new year ‚Äî these offers could drop after the deadline.

My Recommendation

If you’re new to points: Get the no-annual-fee Hilton card. Zero risk, 100,000 points, and you can upgrade later.

If you’re ready to commit: Get the Hilton Surpass. It’s the best balance of bonus, benefits, and annual fee for pet travelers.

If you love Kimpton: Get the IHG Premier. No other hotel chain treats dogs as well as Kimpton, and 140,000 points is a strong bonus.

If you can handle two cards: Get BOTH the Hilton Surpass and IHG Premier. You’ll have 295,000+ points across two programs, covering almost any pet-friendly destination.

item.title: Quiz: Which Hotel Credit Card Is Best for Dog Travelers?
item.description:
Not sure which hotel credit card is right for you and your pup? There are a lot of options ‚Äî Hilton, IHG, Marriott, Chase ‚Äî and the best one depends on your dog’s size, how often you travel, and what perks matter most.

Answer 7 quick questions and we’ll match you with the right card.

Why Your Dog’s Size Matters

Most hotel chains have weight limits (typically 50-75 lbs). If you have a larger dog, your card strategy should account for that:

  • Under 50 lbs: You’re welcome almost everywhere. Hilton and Marriott cards work great.
  • 50-75 lbs: Still good options, but check policies before booking.
  • 75+ lbs: Kimpton (IHG) is your best friend ‚Äî no weight limits, no breed restrictions, no pet fees.

If weight limits are a constant headache, IHG cards or Chase Sapphire (which transfers to IHG) should be on your radar.

The Quick Version

Hilton Surpass $150 Regular travelers who want Gold + free night
Hilton (no fee) $0 Beginners, no risk
IHG Premier $99 Large dogs, Kimpton stays
IHG Traveler $0 Large dogs, no fee commitment
